description:
Gasterosteus aculeatus aculeatus, commonly known as the three-spined stickleback, is a small freshwater and brackish water fish species that belongs to the family Gasterosteidae. This subspecies is native to coastal regions of the Northern Hemisphere, including Europe, Asia, and North America.

The three-spined stickleback is characterized by its distinctive dorsal spines, typically three in number, which can be erected as a defense mechanism. The body is laterally compressed and covered in bony plates along the sides. The coloration of this fish can vary, ranging from olive-green to brown, with darker bands or spots on the sides.

Gasterosteus aculeatus aculeatus is an important model organism in evolutionary biology and behavioral ecology due to its rapid adaptation to various environmental conditions, such as changes in salinity, predation, and resource availability. This subspecies exhibits complex mating behaviors, with the male constructing elaborate nests and engaging in territorial displays to attract females.

The three-spined stickleback plays a crucial role in the aquatic food web, serving as a prey item for larger predatory fish, birds, and other aquatic organisms. Its adaptability and ecological significance make it a valuable subject for scientific research and conservation efforts.
